title: Stakeholder Identification & Prioritization
description: Master the Salience Model to identify and prioritize stakeholders using Power, Legitimacy, and Urgency dimensions.
objectives: Apply the Salience Model (Power, Legitimacy, Urgency) to prioritize stakeholders using 3-dimensional analysis
Classify stakeholder types based on Salience dimensions (Definitive, Dominant, Dangerous, Dependent)
Match stakeholders with appropriate expectations based on their salience profile
Preview the Power-Interest Grid framework as a practical simplification of Salience Model

screens.headline: Prioritize Stakeholders Like an Expert

dialogue.text: Your restaurant's soft launch had mixed reviews. Four stakeholders, four agendas. Who demands your attention FIRST? Assess each stakeholder across three dimensions: Power (can they influence success?), Legitimacy (do they have a rightful stake?), Urgency (is their claim time-sensitive?). This is the Salience Model—how experts prioritize when everyone seems important.

screens.learningHook: Not all stakeholders are created equal. The Salience Model helps you prioritize by assessing THREE dimensions simultaneously: Power, Legitimacy, and Urgency.

screens.title: Assess Stakeholders Using the Salience Model
screens.instructions: Rate each stakeholder across three dimensions (Power, Legitimacy, Urgency), then select their critical expectation.

scenarios.title: Ava Thompson - Lead Investor
description: Provided $150K capital, expects quarterly ROI reports
Has power to approve or block budget decisions
Upcoming board meeting creates time pressure

legitimacy.question: Do they have a rightful stake?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Ava has high Power (controls funding), high Legitimacy (financial stake), and high Urgency (board meetings create time pressure). She is a Definitive Stakeholder requiring immediate attention.
feedback.incorrect: Ava controls funding (High Power), has financial stake (High Legitimacy), and faces board meeting deadlines (High Urgency). All three dimensions are high.

feedback.correct: Correct! As an investor, Ava's primary concern is return on investment and regular financial reporting.
feedback.incorrect: While risk and milestones matter, Ava's primary expectation as an investor is ROI reporting and financial transparency.

scenarios.title: Inspector Lee - City Inspector
description: Regulatory authority for health and safety compliance
Can block operations if compliance issues arise
No immediate deadline but urgency spikes near inspections

questions.question: Rate Inspector Lee across three dimensions:

legitimacy.question: Do they have a rightful stake?

feedback.correct: Excellent! Inspector Lee has high Power (can shut down operations) and high Legitimacy (legal authority), but low Urgency in routine periods. He's a Dominant Stakeholder.
feedback.incorrect: Inspector Lee has regulatory authority (High Power and Legitimacy), but his urgency is LOW in routine periods—it only spikes near compliance deadlines.

questions.question: Select Inspector Lee's ONE critical expectation:

feedback.correct: Perfect! As a health inspector, Lee's primary concern is documented compliance evidence.
feedback.incorrect: Inspector Lee's main focus is compliance documentation. Remediation and deadlines are secondary.

scenarios.title: Chef Marco - Head Chef
description: Influences team and operations but limited strategic authority
Service quality impacts are immediate with daily pressure

questions.question: Rate Chef Marco across three dimensions:

legitimacy.question: Do they have a rightful stake?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Chef Marco has Moderate Power (influences operations but limited strategic authority), High Legitimacy (internal operational role), and High Urgency (daily service quality pressure). He's a Dependent Stakeholder.
feedback.incorrect: Chef Marco has MODERATE Power (not strategic decision-maker), but HIGH Legitimacy (rightful operational role) and HIGH Urgency (daily service pressure).

questions.question: Select Chef Marco's ONE critical expectation:

feedback.correct: Correct! As head chef, Marco's primary concern is having reliable equipment to execute the menu.
feedback.incorrect: While staffing and menu matter, equipment reliability is Chef Marco's critical operational need.

scenarios.title: Kiki - Food Blogger
description: Influential local food critic with social media following
Can shape public sentiment but no formal authority
Social media posts create immediate public pressure

legitimacy.question: Do they have a rightful stake?

feedback.correct: Excellent! Kiki has Moderate Power (can influence reputation), Low Legitimacy (no formal stake), and High Urgency (social media creates immediate pressure). She's a Dangerous Stakeholder to manage carefully.
feedback.incorrect: Kiki has low formal Power and no Legitimacy (external influencer), but HIGH Urgency due to social media's immediate impact. This makes her a Dangerous Stakeholder.

feedback.correct: Perfect! As a food blogger, Kiki's primary need is a compelling story angle for her content.
feedback.incorrect: While access and photos help, Kiki's critical expectation as a content creator is the story narrative.

content.definition: The Salience Model assesses stakeholders based on THREE dimensions simultaneously to determine priority.

dimensions.name: Power
dimensions.question: Can they impose their will on the project?
dimensions.explanation: Ability to influence project success (budget approval, regulatory shutdown, team morale)

dimensions.name: Legitimacy
dimensions.question: Do they have a valid reason to be at the table?
dimensions.explanation: Rightful or legal claim to be involved in the project

dimensions.name: Urgency
dimensions.question: Is their concern immediate or can it wait?
dimensions.explanation: Time sensitivity of their claim or demand

blocks.title: Seven Stakeholder Types Based on Salience

types.name: Definitive Stakeholders
types.strategy: Immediate attention required, frequent communication, involve in key decisions
types.example: Ava (Investor) - Has all three dimensions high

types.name: Dominant Stakeholders
types.strategy: Keep satisfied, but don't overwhelm with daily updates
types.example: Inspector Lee - Power + Legitimacy, urgency spikes near deadlines

types.name: Dependent Stakeholders
types.strategy: Regular updates, operational support, address concerns promptly
types.example: Chef Marco - Legitimacy + Urgency, limited strategic power

types.name: Dangerous Stakeholders
types.strategy: Manage carefully, balance responsiveness with boundaries
types.example: Kiki (Blogger) - Can influence reputation + trending urgency, no formal stake

content.insight: Stakeholder types help you prioritize WHO needs attention WHEN based on their dimension combinations.

content.intro: The Salience Model is comprehensive, but what about day-to-day stakeholder management? Enter the Power-Interest Grid—a practical 2×2 tool that simplifies Salience for everyday PM work.

mapping.gridQuadrant: Keep Informed or Monitor (depends on power level)

content.keyInsight: Power-Interest Grid combines Legitimacy + Urgency into 'Interest.' It's faster to use daily, but Salience gives you deeper insights when stakeholder dynamics are complex.
content.teaser: In the next lesson (B1L2), you'll master the Power-Interest Grid—classifying 12 stakeholders and learning engagement strategies for each quadrant.

ava_correct.text: You correctly identified that I need immediate attention across all three dimensions. My funding gates and board meetings create real time pressure.

inspector_correct.text: Perfect understanding. I have high power and legal authority, but my urgency is low in routine periods—it only spikes near compliance deadlines.

marco_correct.text: You got it. I have high legitimacy in operations and daily urgency, but my strategic power is limited. I need regular support, not close strategic management.

kiki_correct.text: Excellent! You recognized that I can create urgency through social media despite lacking formal authority. That makes me a stakeholder to manage carefully.

screens.title: Apply Salience to New Stakeholder: DashCart Delivery Partner
screens.context: A delivery partner (DashCart) has just joined your restaurant ecosystem. They'll handle all delivery operations starting next week.

scenario.title: DashCart - Delivery Partner
details: Third-party delivery service, handles 40% of revenue stream
Contractual partner, can be replaced but would cause short-term disruption
Launch in 1 week, needs operational alignment immediately

legitimacy.question: Do they have a rightful stake?

feedback.correct: Perfect! DashCart has Moderate Power (affects delivery but replaceable), High Legitimacy (contractual partner), and Moderate-High Urgency (1-week launch creates time pressure).
feedback.incorrect: DashCart has moderate Power (can disrupt but replaceable), moderate-high Legitimacy (contractual partner), and moderate-high Urgency (1-week launch).

questions.question: Which Power-Interest Grid quadrant does DashCart belong in?

feedback.correct: Correct! DashCart maps to 'Keep Informed'—they need regular operational updates and proactive communication, but don't require close management.
feedback.incorrect: DashCart has moderate power and moderate-high interest. They belong in 'Keep Informed' quadrant—regular updates without close strategic management.

questions.question: Explain your reasoning (minimum 50 characters):
questions.placeholder: DashCart has [Power level] because... Their Legitimacy is [level] because... Their Urgency is [level] because... This maps to [quadrant] because...

feedback.correct: Good explanation linking Salience dimensions to Grid quadrant mapping.
feedback.partial: Your reasoning is brief. Expand on how Salience dimensions map to the Power-Interest Grid.
feedback.incorrect: Review how Salience dimensions (Power, Legitimacy, Urgency) combine to determine Power-Interest Grid placement.

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: You've successfully prioritized stakeholders using the Salience Model—a comprehensive 3-dimensional framework that captures Power, Legitimacy, and Urgency.
takeaways: Salience Model assesses stakeholders across 3 dimensions: Power (ability to impose will), Legitimacy (rightful stake), Urgency (time sensitivity)
Stakeholder Types: Definitive (all 3 high) = HIGHEST priority, Dominant (Power + Legitimacy), Dependent (Legitimacy + Urgency), Dangerous (Power + Urgency)
Bridge to Power-Interest Grid: Salience = comprehensive analysis (3D), Power-Interest Grid = practical tool (2D combining Legitimacy + Urgency into Interest)
Stakeholder classifications are dynamic—reassess throughout project lifecycle as power, legitimacy, and urgency change

characterClosing.text: I've learned to think comprehensively about stakeholder prioritization. The Salience Model helps me see WHO needs attention and WHY, based on their Power, Legitimacy, and Urgency profile.
